study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the immunostimulatory potential and safety of trehalose 6,6' dimycolate (TDM) encapsulated in a lipid nanocarrier as a novel tuberculosis (TB) vaccine candidate.
results_summary: The study found that encapsulating TDM in cubosome lipid nanocarriers improved its solubility, reduced toxicity, and elicited a strong proinflammatory cytokine response in MTB-infected macrophages, enhancing antigen processing and presentation to CD4 T cells. Mathematical modeling supported its potential efficacy in vivo.
population_specificity: MTB-infected macrophages (in vitro study).
effective_dosage: 1 mol % TDM encapsulated in lipid monoolein (MO) cubosomes.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the anti-amyloidogenic performance of trehalose-conjugated polycarbonate-co-lactide nanoparticles in inhibiting amyloid beta peptide aggregation and disintegrating mature amyloid fibrils.
results_summary: The poly(trehalose) nanoparticle effectively inhibited amyloid beta peptide aggregation, disintegrated mature fibrils, reduced cellular stress from amyloid β oligomers, and improved cell viability. The biodegradable polycarbonate components enhanced its potential as an anti-amyloidogenic material.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro or preclinical study implied).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effectiveness of 10% trehalose oral spray in relieving radiation-induced xerostomia compared to a carboxymethylcellulose (CMC) spray.
results_summary: The study found that 10% trehalose spray significantly improved salivary pH and unstimulated salivary flow rate compared to CMC. While both sprays improved quality-of-life dimensions (physical, pain/discomfort, psychological), there was no significant difference in total XeQoLs scores between trehalose and CMC.
population_specificity: Head and neck cancer patients who completed radiotherapy and experienced radiation-induced xerostomia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the immunostimulatory properties and mode of action of an aryl-functionalized trehalose glycolipid (AF-2), particularly its Mincle-dependent and independent effects.
results_summary: AF-2 induced cytokine and chemokine release (e.g., IL-6, MIP-2, TNF-α) via Mincle signaling and triggered Mincle-independent pyroptosis, leading to IL-1β production and lytic cell death through NLRP3 inflammasome activation. The study revealed a novel mechanism of action for plate-coated AF-2, differing from typical trehalose glycolipid behavior.
population_specificity: Bone marrow-derived macrophages (BMDM) from WT and Mincle-/- mice, murine RAW264.7 cells, and human monocytes.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of artificial tears containing trehalose and hyaluronic acid in improving dry eye disease symptoms in women of mixed-hormonal status (42-54 years) and postmenopausal women (≥55 years).
results_summary: The treatment significantly reduced dry eye symptoms, conjunctival hyperemia, and improved tear break-up time in both age groups, with more pronounced effects in women aged 42-54 years. No significant differences were observed between age groups except for visual acuity.
population_specificity: Women aged 42-54 years (mixed-hormonal status) and ≥55 years (postmenopausal) with moderate to severe dry eye disease.
effective_dosage: One drop of artificial tears containing trehalose (3%) and hyaluronic acid (0.15%) instilled in each eye 3 to 6 times daily.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether trehalose could attenuate the progression of abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) by reducing inflammation and restoring smooth muscle cell contractile phenotype through autophagy induction.
results_summary: Trehalose reduced aortic dilation, improved elastin degradation, restored smooth muscle cell contractile markers, decreased apoptosis and leukocyte infiltration, and induced autophagy markers in a mouse model of AAA.
population_specificity: Mouse model of elastase-induced abdominal aortic aneurysm.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of trehalose, ascorbic acid, and Y-27632 on the proliferation and survival rate of Wharton jelly mesenchymal stem cells after cryopreservation.
results_summary: The study found that 75 mM trehalose significantly increased post-thaw viability, cell proliferation, and reduced doubling time of the cells. Enhanced viability, proliferation, and attachment were also observed when trehalose was used in pretreatment and freezing medium.
population_specificity: Human umbilical cord Wharton jelly mesenchymal stem cells.
study_duration: 24 hours of pretreatment and post-thaw assessment.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether trehalose supplementation improves vascular function in middle-aged and older adults, specifically focusing on resistance artery endothelial function and nitric oxide bioavailability.
results_summary: Trehalose supplementation improved resistance artery endothelial function by ~30% and increased endothelium-independent dilation, likely due to enhanced nitric oxide bioavailability and smooth muscle sensitivity. However, these benefits were not observed in subjects with significant body weight changes, and trehalose had no effect on conduit artery function, arterial stiffness, or inflammatory markers.
population_specificity: Healthy adults aged 50-77 years.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether saponins from Tribulus terrestris could alleviate neuropathic pain in rats by inhibiting the TLR4/NF-κB pathway.
results_summary: Tribulus terrestris at 100 mg/kg and 200 mg/kg doses reduced neuropathic pain symptoms, improved histopathological changes, and lowered inflammatory cytokines (IL-1β, IL-6) by inhibiting the TLR4/NF-κB pathway, comparable to pregabalin.
population_specificity: Male rats with chronic constriction injury (CCI) of the sciatic nerve.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if a new vitrification solution containing hydroxypropyl cellulose (HPC) and trehalose was as effective and safe as conventional solutions using serum substitute supplement (SSS) and sucrose for human oocyte preservation.
results_summary: The study found no significant differences in survival, implantation, pregnancy, or delivery rates between the HPC + trehalose and SSS + sucrose groups, but the HPC + trehalose group showed a higher blastocyst rate. The new formulation was deemed safe and effective for oocyte vitrification.
population_specificity: Ovum donation cycles (218 cycles with 2532 oocytes in the study group, 214 cycles with 2353 oocytes in the control group).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of harvest time on the content of bioactive components in different parts of Tribulus Terrestris and compare their antihypertensive effects.
results_summary: The study found that Tribulus Terrestris leaves (TTL) had higher total saponin content than the fruit (TTF) or stems (TTS), and TTL exhibited better antihypertensive effects, improving blood pressure, serum indexes, and thoracic aorta morphology. The optimal harvest periods varied by plant part, with TTF best harvested from August 11 to September 1, and TTS/TTL from July 21 to September 11.
population_specificity: Not specified (likely animal or in vitro models based on the abstract).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to study the agro-morphological and phytochemical diversity of Tribulus Terrestris from 24 regions in Iran and assess its anti-proliferative activity against human prostate cancer cells (PC3).
results_summary: The study found significant variation in phytochemical traits and anti-proliferative activity among T. terrestris populations, with IC50 values ranging from 15.02 to 27.11 µg/ml against PC3 cells. The SBU population showed superior morphological traits, while the RAF population had the highest saponin content.
population_specificity: T. terrestris collected from 24 geographical regions in Iran.
effective_dosage: Not specified (IC50 values provided for extracts).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the pro-apoptotic effects and anti-inflammatory mechanisms of gross saponins of Tribulus terrestris (GSTT) on rheumatoid arthritis fibroblast-like synoviocytes (RA-FLSs) and its therapeutic potential for rheumatoid arthritis (RA).
results_summary: GSTT significantly promoted apoptosis of RA-FLSs, reduced pro-inflammatory cytokine levels, lowered the Bcl-2/Bax ratio, and inhibited JNK and p38 phosphorylation. In vivo, GSTT improved clinical RA scores, reduced synovial inflammation, and decreased serum pro-inflammatory cytokine levels.
population_specificity: Rheumatoid arthritis fibroblast-like synoviocytes (RA-FLSs) and an in vivo RA model.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate Tribulus Terrestris's protective effects against carboplatin-induced liver and kidney damage in rats.
results_summary: Tribulus Terrestris significantly reduced creatinine and aspartate transaminase levels, reversed oxidative stress markers, decreased interleukin 6, and restored normal liver and kidney architecture in rats treated with carboplatin.
population_specificity: Thirty rats divided into control, carboplatin-only, and three Tribulus Terrestris treatment groups.
effective_dosage: 1 g/kg, 1.25 g/kg, and 1.5 g/kg for 14 days.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether Tribulus terrestris (Tt) could attenuate cognitive deficits and exhibit anxiolytic and antidepressant effects in scopolamine-induced amnesia in zebrafish.
results_summary: Tt administration (1, 3, and 6 mg/L) for 10 days averted scopolamine-induced anxiety and cognitive deficits in zebrafish, with flavonoids like kaempferol and quercetin identified as potential phytopharmaceuticals for anxiety-related disorders.
population_specificity: Zebrafish with scopolamine-induced amnesia.

study_goal: The study does not examine Tribulus Terrestris; it focuses on the cardioprotective effects of silver nanoparticles (AgNPs) on isoproterenol-induced myocardial infarction in mice.
results_summary: The study does not report any findings related to Tribulus Terrestris.
population_specificity: Mice with induced myocardial infarction.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the phytochemical composition of Tribulus terrestris seed extract and evaluate its cytotoxic, pro-apoptotic, antioxidant, anti-inflammatory, and antimicrobial activities against oral cancer cells.
results_summary: The study found that Tribulus terrestris seed extract exhibited concentration-dependent cytotoxicity against oral cancer cells, pro-apoptotic effects, significant antioxidant and anti-inflammatory activities, and antimicrobial efficacy against various pathogens.
population_specificity: Oral cancer cells (in vitro study)
effective_dosage: 100 μg/mL (concentration used for significant growth inhibition)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Tribulus Terrestris (bindii) extract, combined with swim exercise, improves memory and reduces oxidative stress markers in old male rats.
results_summary: The study found that Tribulus Terrestris extract combined with swimming exercise improved spatial and avoidance memory in old rats, likely by reducing oxidative stress, as evidenced by increased catalase (CAT) and antioxidant capacity (TAC) and decreased malondialdehyde (MDA). No significant effect was observed on reference memory error in the radial maze.
population_specificity: Old male Wistar rats (400-500 g) and young male Wistar rats.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to elucidate the mechanisms of Tribulus Terrestris in treating diabetes mellitus and investigate the therapeutic effects of its water extract, small molecular components, and saccharides.
results_summary: Tribulus Terrestris improved glucolipid metabolism, intestinal barrier integrity, inflammation, and insulin resistance in T2DM rats. It modulated gut microbiota and metabolites, influencing metabolic pathways like tryptophan, fatty acid, and bile acid metabolism.
population_specificity: Type 2 diabetic rats

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the combined effects of ginseng, Tribulus terrestris, and L-arginine on improving sexual performance in individuals with erectile dysfunction.
results_summary: The herbal treatment group showed significant improvement in IIEF-5 scores, particularly in non-diabetic patients, but no significant difference was observed in diabetic patients compared to the placebo group.
population_specificity: 98 men with erectile dysfunction (both diabetic and non-diabetic).
effective_dosage: Each herbal tablet contained 100 mg of protodioscin (from Tribulus terrestris), 35 mg of ginsenosides, and 250 mg of L-arginine; total daily dosage not specified.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the anti-inflammatory mechanisms of gross saponins from Tribulus terrestris L. fruit in vitro using a lipopolysaccharide-induced BV2 cells model.
results_summary: The saponins reduced nitric oxide release and inflammatory cytokines (TNF-α, IL-1β, IL-6) in BV2 cells, reversed metabolic perturbations, and suppressed inflammatory signaling pathways, primarily via glycerophospholipid, tryptophan, and purine metabolism regulation.
population_specificity: BV2 microglial cells (in vitro study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to uncover the mechanisms by which gross saponins of Tribulus terrestris (GSTTF) protect against ischemic stroke.
results_summary: GSTTF significantly reduced elevated CRP, IL-6, and Ca2+ levels in ischemic stroke models and reversed abnormal mRNA expression in brain tissues, likely through suppression of calcium ion and the MyD88/IKK/NF-κB signaling pathway.
population_specificity: Rat brain tissues affected by ischemic stroke models.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Tribulus terrestris supplementation affects testicular morphology and sperm parameters in male rats.
results_summary: The study found no significant differences in sperm concentration, motility, viability, or most testicular morphometric parameters between treated and control groups. However, seminiferous epithelium height and tubular lumen surface density increased slightly in the treated group.
population_specificity: Male rats

study_goal: The researchers aimed to study the combined effects of Tribulus Terrestris and vitamin E on the histological condition of the testicle and epididymis in rabbits, focusing on sperm formation and differentiation.
results_summary: The study found that Tribulus Terrestris, especially when combined with vitamin E, positively affected spermatogonia and spermatocytes, increased sperm frequency in the epididymis, and showed no negative histological effects. The seminiferous tubules showed significant improvements in spermatogenic activity compared to the control group.
population_specificity: 28 healthy male rabbits (445-950 g, 2.0-3.0 months old)
effective_dosage: 1 g of Tribulus Terrestris daily, with or without 60 mg of vitamin E

study_goal: The researchers aimed to study the anti-inflammatory activity of a thick extract of Tribulus terrestris on carrageenan and zymosan inflammation models in rats.
results_summary: The thick extract of Tribulus terrestris showed anti-inflammatory activity at doses of 50-200 mg/kg, with efficacy comparable to sodium diclofenac (8.0 mg/kg) in carrageenan inflammation and corvitin (10 mg/kg) in zymosan inflammation, indicating anticyclogenase and antilipoxygenase properties.
population_specificity: Rats (animal model)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the anti-breast cancer effects of Tribulus Terrestris and explore its potential mechanisms of action.
results_summary: Tribulus Terrestris significantly reduced tumor size and weight in a mouse model of breast cancer, with a tumor inhibitory rate exceeding 26%. The study identified key molecular pathways, including sphingolipid metabolism, as potential mechanisms for its anti-cancer effects.
population_specificity: Mouse model of breast cancer (4T1 cells).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the anti-liver cancer activity of Tribulus Terrestris (TT) and its underlying mechanisms, focusing on apoptosis regulation and signaling pathways.
results_summary: TT demonstrated significant antitumor activity in a liver cancer mouse model, reducing tumor size and weight by over 44%, and activated apoptotic pathways by altering protein levels (e.g., increasing Bax, Caspase3, and decreasing Bcl2). Metabolomics analysis identified 47 differential metabolites and 66 affected pathways.
population_specificity: Balb/c mice with H22 cell-induced liver cancer.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to biosynthesize silver nanoparticles using Tribulus terrestris seed extract and evaluate their anti-diabetic properties.
results_summary: The study found that TT-AgNPs exhibited significant anti-diabetic effects, including high glucose uptake (78.45% at 80 µg/mL), glucose adsorption (10.40% at 30 mM), and alpha-amylase inhibition (75.68% at 100 µg/mL). In vivo results showed a significant drop in blood sugar levels in diabetic mice after 30 days of treatment.
population_specificity: Streptozotocin-induced diabetic mice.
effective_dosage: 80 µg/mL (glucose uptake), 30 mM (glucose adsorption), 100 µg/mL (alpha-amylase assay).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify and validate α-glucosidase inhibitors in Tribulus terrestris L. for potential treatment of type 2 diabetes.
results_summary: The study identified 15 ligands from Tribulus terrestris, including steroidal saponins, flavonoids, and alkaloids, which showed inhibitory effects on α-glucosidase. These findings were further validated through in vivo experiments and molecular docking simulations.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro and in vivo models used)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the protective effects of TT15 (Tribulus terrestris extract) on ischemic stroke in MCAO rats and identify its potential targets and mechanisms of action.
results_summary: TT15 reduced infarct volume and improved neurological defect scores in MCAO rats, restored metabolic disturbances via multiple pathways, and showed binding affinity with key enzymes (PLA2 and POD) through molecular docking.
population_specificity: Middle cerebral artery occlusion (MCAO) rats (animal model).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify the pathogen causing anthracnose in Tribulus Terrestris and confirm its pathogenicity.
results_summary: The study identified Colletotrichum truncatum as the pathogen causing anthracnose in Tribulus Terrestris, confirmed its pathogenicity through inoculation tests, and provided genetic and morphological characterization.
population_specificity: Tribulus Terrestris plants (cultivar: landrace) in Fushun County, Liaoning Province, China.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the therapeutic effects of Tribulus Terrestris cell biomass on reducing weight gain and metabolic complications in rats with alimentary-induced obesity.
results_summary: Tribulus Terrestris cell biomass reduced weight gain, fat mass, and improved glucose and cholesterol levels in obese rats, though its hypocholesterolemic activity was less pronounced compared to other tested species.
population_specificity: Rat models with alimentary-induced obesity.
effective_dosage: 100 mg/g body weight (water infusion of dry cell biomass).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether 6 weeks of Tribulus Terrestris supplementation could mitigate exercise-induced muscle damage, inflammation, and oxidative stress in trained athletes.
results_summary: Tribulus Terrestris supplementation significantly improved Lactate Dehydrogenase (LDH), C-reactive protein (CRP), and Total Antioxidant Status (TAS) levels compared to placebo, suggesting potential benefits in reducing oxidative stress and inflammation. However, no significant decreases in muscle damage or inflammation biomarkers were observed, though a slight downward trend was noted after 6 weeks.
population_specificity: Thirty trained male CrossFit® athletes.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the protective effects of Tribulus terrestris (GSTTF) on ischemic stroke using a rat model and explore its underlying anti-inflammatory mechanisms.
results_summary: GSTTF administration reduced brain infarction volume, improved neurobehavioral scores in MCAO rats, and lowered TNF-α and IL-6 levels by inhibiting the TLR4/MyD88/NF-κB pathway. Metabolomics identified key pathways (glycerophospholipid, sphingolipid, and arachidonic acid metabolism) linked to its anti-inflammatory effects.
population_specificity: Middle cerebral artery occlusion (MCAO) rat model

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether fructose consumption affects the anti-tumor efficacy of Tribulus terrestris extract in neuroblastoma cells.
results_summary: Tribulus terrestris extract at 100 ng/ml reduced neuroblastoma cell viability and suppressed mitochondrial functions, but these effects were blunted in a fructose-enriched environment. Lower dosages (0.01 and 1 ng/ml) unexpectedly enhanced cell viability in the fructose milieu.
population_specificity: Mouse neuroblastoma cell line (Neuro 2a cells)
interactions: Fructose (20 mM) blunted the therapeutic effects of Tribulus terrestris.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effectiveness of Tribulus terrestris (TT) as an herbal supplement with antioxidant and anti-inflammatory properties on nutritional, oxidative, inflammatory, and anti-inflammatory status, as well as sports performance in recreational runners.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide results, as the study appears to be in progress or not yet concluded. The outcomes will assess changes in oxidative stress, anti-inflammatory biomarkers, and sports performance.
population_specificity: Recreational runners from Tabriz stadiums, Iran.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to characterize the chemical components of Tribulus terrestris and evaluate its α-glucosidase inhibition activity across different origins.
results_summary: The study identified 155 chemicals in Tribulus terrestris, with steroidal saponins showing significant α-glucosidase inhibition activity, particularly in samples from Inner Mongolia. Principal component analysis revealed 13 chemical markers with significant content differences among samples from three regions.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a furostanol saponins enriched extract (FSEE) of Tribulus terrestris L. exhibits anti-atherosclerotic effects by inhibiting vascular smooth muscle cell (VSMC) proliferation and to investigate its molecular mechanism.
results_summary: FSEE significantly reduced atherosclerotic plaque area in mice, inhibited VSMC proliferation and migration, and suppressed Akt/MEK/ERK signaling. The active components JL-6, tigogenin, and hecogenin also attenuated VSMC proliferation.
population_specificity: Apolipoprotein-E deficient (ApoE-/-) mice and rat thoracic smooth muscle cell A7r5.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of Eucommia ulmoides-Tribulus terrestris (EU-TT) on blood pressure and hypothalamus morphology in aging spontaneously hypertensive rats (SHRs) and identify potential molecular targets.
results_summary: EU-TT significantly reduced systolic and diastolic blood pressure, improved hypothalamus morphology, and modulated the MAPK signaling pathway, as evidenced by proteomic and molecular analyses.
population_specificity: Aging spontaneously hypertensive rats (SHRs)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the provenance, constituents, properties, and physiological effects of Tribulus Terrestris, particularly its influence on male and female reproductive processes and dysfunctions.
results_summary: The study found that Tribulus Terrestris influences a wide range of physiological processes, acting as a stimulator for male and female reproductive functions, including sexual behavior, hormone regulation, gamete quality, and fecundity, with potential applications for improving libido and treating infertility.
population_specificity: Not specified (general review of available literature).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the potential mechanisms of the EUO-TT drug pair (including Tribulus Terrestris) in treating hypertension-associated neurovascular lesions and ischemic stroke via the ferroptosis pathway.
results_summary: The study identified 36 active compounds in the EUO-TT drug pair, with 12 showing strong binding to target proteins (CHRM1, NR3C1, ADRB2, OPRD1) linked to neuroactive ligand-receptor interactions and ferroptosis. The constructed nomogram model suggested these targets as risk markers for ischemic stroke.
population_specificity: Not specified (in silico and molecular docking study).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the reno-protective mechanism of Tribulus terrestris (TrT) on Angiotensin II-induced hypertensive renal injury, focusing on miRNA-mRNA interactions.
results_summary: TrT treatment upregulated miR-155-5p, which negatively regulated H2AC6 expression, demonstrating a reno-protective effect against hypertensive renal injury. The study identified key miRNA-mRNA interactions involved in this protective mechanism.
population_specificity: Glomerular endothelial cells in an Angiotensin II-induced hypertensive renal injury model.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Tribulus Terrestris supplementation improves body composition, hormonal response, and performance in CrossFit® athletes.
results_summary: TT supplementation did not significantly enhance performance or body composition but showed a potential testosterone-boosting effect, aiding recovery and mitigating fatigue. Bench press performance and testosterone levels showed significant improvements.
population_specificity: 30 healthy CrossFit®-trained males

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the antiglycation and antioxidant activities of Tribulus terrestris crude dry extract and saponin fraction, and evaluate the efficiency of microencapsulation in preserving these properties.
results_summary: The study found that both crude dry extract and saponin fraction exhibited significant antiglycation and antioxidant activities, with microencapsulation effectively maintaining these properties post-release. The saponin fraction showed particularly high inhibition of advanced glycation end-product formation (89.89%) and strong antioxidant performance in various assays.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the therapeutic potential of bioreactor-grown Tribulus terrestris cell cultures in treating carbohydrate metabolism disorders (CMDs) in laboratory rats.
results_summary: Tribulus terrestris significantly reduced blood glucose levels in adrenaline-induced hyperglycemia and improved carbohydrate and lipid metabolism in streptozotocin-induced type 2 diabetes mellitus, evidenced by reduced daily diuresis, blood-glucose levels, blood content in urine, and total cholesterol.
population_specificity: Laboratory rats with induced hyperglycemia and type 2 diabetes mellitus.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential hepatorenal toxicity of Terrestrosin D (TED), a major spirostanol saponin in Tribulus Terrestris, and explore its possible mechanism.
results_summary: The study found that TED exhibited potential hepatorenal toxicity in both in vitro and in vivo studies, though the effects were reversible after discontinuation. Toxicokinetic and tissue distribution studies indicated dose-dependent accumulation of TED in the liver and kidneys.
population_specificity: Sprague-Dawley (SD) rats

study_goal: The researchers aimed to isolate and identify the active anticancer compound in Tribulus terrestris seed saponin extract and evaluate its binding affinity with cellular target proteins.
results_summary: The study identified Nuatigenin, a steroidal saponin, as the active compound in the seed extract with high cytotoxicity against human breast cancer cells. In silico docking revealed strong binding affinity with apoptotic proteins and cell surface receptors, suggesting potential therapeutic use for breast cancer.
population_specificity: Human breast cancer cells (in vitro study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of Tribulus terrestris in treating sexual dysfunction in pre and postmenopausal women and its effect on clitoral artery vascular resistance.
results_summary: Tribulus terrestris improved sexual function in both pre and postmenopausal women, as measured by FSFI and QS-F questionnaires, with no reported side effects. It also increased total, free, and bioavailable testosterone levels.
population_specificity: Pre and postmenopausal women with sexual dysfunction.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether Tribulus terrestris (TT) extracts are justified for use in diabetes and diabetes complications by examining their mechanisms of action.
results_summary: Both TT preparations reduced elevated blood glucose levels in diabetic rats. The TT extract with high protodioscin content (TT-HPC) significantly increased FSH and testosterone levels compared to the diabetic control group, suggesting a potential FSH-linked pathway for testosterone modulation.
population_specificity: Diabetic rats

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a saponin-rich extract of Tribulus Terrestris could alleviate inflammatory burden, insulin resistance, adipokine expression, and related reproductive pathologies in a model of dietary obesity in female rats.
results_summary: Tribulus Terrestris saponins (TTS) reduced body weight gain, serum triglycerides, and insulin resistance in obese rats. It also improved inflammatory cytokine levels, corrected hormonal disturbances, and ameliorated ovarian pathologies.
population_specificity: Female rats with diet-induced obesity.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the blood pressure-lowering effect of Tribulus terrestris (Khār-i-khasak) in prehypertensive individuals.
results_summary: The study found a significant decline in both systolic and diastolic blood pressure in the test group compared to placebo, with no cases of full-blown hypertension during follow-up. Safety parameters remained within normal limits.
population_specificity: Prehypertensive individuals over 18 years of age.
effective_dosage: 6g of powdered dried fruits in three divided doses daily.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to analyze the elemental composition of Tribulus terrestris and assess how it varies based on geographic growth conditions.
results_summary: The study identified 26 essential and trace elements in T. terrestris, confirming that its elemental composition varies depending on the habitat. The plant's ability to accumulate elements is influenced by its geographic growth location.
population_specificity: Cultivated T. terrestris from Russia and wild-growing samples from China.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of Tribulus terrestris ethanol extract (TEE) on the freezability and quality of goat epididymal spermatozoa during cryopreservation.
results_summary: Supplementation with 50 μg/ml TEE significantly improved sperm motility, viability, and membrane integrity while reducing DNA fragmentation and malondialdehyde levels. Combining TEE with trehalose further enhanced these protective effects.
population_specificity: Goat epididymal spermatozoa

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the anti-Parkinson's activity of Tribulus terrestris methanol extract (TTME) by assessing its effects on behavioral, biochemical, and molecular markers in a rat model of Parkinson's disease.
results_summary: TTME demonstrated significant dose-dependent improvements in behavioral symptoms, restored antioxidant enzyme levels, reduced oxidative stress markers, and downregulated mRNA expression of pro-inflammatory cytokines and α-synuclein in Parkinson's disease rats.
population_specificity: Haloperidol-induced Parkinson's disease model in rats.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the protective effect of gross saponins of Tribulus terrestris L. fruit (GSTTF) against ischemic stroke in rats and explore its potential therapeutic mechanisms.
results_summary: GSTTF showed neuroprotective effects by reversing metabolic disturbances caused by ischemic stroke in rats, with network pharmacology identifying 24 potential therapeutic targets. Molecular docking confirmed active compounds could bind to key targets (HSD11B1 and AR).
population_specificity: Rats with middle cerebral artery occlusion (MCAO)-induced ischemic stroke.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the role of intestinal microbiota and fecal metabolism in the antihypertensive effects of a combination of Eucommia ulmoides and Tribulus terrestris (ET) in elderly hypertensive rats.
results_summary: ET treatment reduced blood pressure, improved colonic tissue morphology, and altered the imbalanced microbiota in hypertensive rats, particularly increasing Eubacterium abundance. These changes correlated with altered fecal metabolites, suggesting ET's antihypertensive effects may be mediated by gut microbiota and their metabolites.
population_specificity: Elderly spontaneously hypertensive rats (SHRs, 18 months old) and Wistar-Kyoto (WKY) rats as controls.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effect of Tribulus terrestris (TT) aqueous extract and saponin fraction on the expression of ICAM-1, VCAM-1, and SELE genes in endothelial cells under normal and LPS-induced inflammatory conditions.
results_summary: LPS-induced endothelial cells showed significantly increased expression of ICAM-1, VCAM-1, and SELE genes, which was significantly reduced by treatment with TT aqueous extract and saponin fraction. The findings suggest TT has anti-inflammatory effects that may be beneficial for atherosclerosis prevention/therapy.
population_specificity: Human umbilical vein endothelial cells (HUVEC) and human bone marrow endothelial cells (HBMEC) in vitro.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effectiveness and safety of Tribulus terrestris in treating female sexual dysfunction (FSD) through a systematic review of randomized controlled trials.
results_summary: Tribulus terrestris significantly improved sexual function scores in premenopausal and postmenopausal women after 1 to 3 months of treatment and increased serum testosterone levels in premenopausal women. No serious adverse events were reported, but the certainty of evidence was very low.
population_specificity: Premenopausal and postmenopausal women with female sexual dysfunction (n=279).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the mechanisms by which Tribulus terrestris protects human retinal pigment epithelial cells (ARPE-19) against oxidative stress induced by H2O2.
results_summary: The study found that Tribulus terrestris extract (EE-TT) significantly improved cell viability, reduced apoptosis, and modulated oxidative stress markers in ARPE-19 cells by regulating the PI3K/Akt-Nrf2 signaling pathway. EE-TT also reversed H2O2-induced downregulation of antioxidant genes and increased the expression of key protective genes.
population_specificity: Human retinal pigment epithelial cells (ARPE-19) in vitro.

study_goal: To investigate the anti-inflammatory effects of Tribulus terrestris extract and its saponin fraction on endothelial cells by measuring changes in proteome and expression of adhesion molecules (ICAM-1, VCAM-1, and E-selectin).
results_summary: The study found that Tribulus terrestris extract significantly reduced proteome levels (80 spots) and expression of ICAM-1, VCAM-1, and E-selectin in LPS-induced endothelial cells, with the aqueous extract showing greater anti-inflammatory effects than the saponin fraction alone.
population_specificity: Human umbilical vein endothelial cells (HUVECs) and human bone marrow endothelial cells (HBMECs).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the preventive and curative potential of a statistically optimized aqueous extract of Tribulus terrestris for kidney stones, along with its preclinical safety.
results_summary: The study found that the extract improved renal function, restored normal renal architecture, and modulated urinary crystal morphology. It also demonstrated antioxidant efficacy and reversed p38MAPK upregulation, with no observed adverse effects at 750 mg/kg body weight.
population_specificity: Experimentally induced nephrolithiatic Wistar rats

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the protective effects of Gross Saponins of Tribulus Terrestris Fruit (GSTTF) on ischemic stroke using metabolomics and network pharmacology analysis.
results_summary: GSTTF reversed metabolic deviations caused by ischemic stroke in rats, potentially targeting proteins NOS2 and GSK3B, suggesting neuroprotective effects. The study highlights GSTTF's regulatory role in multiple metabolic pathways but calls for further research to clarify underlying mechanisms.
population_specificity: Rats with middle cerebral artery occlusion (MCAO)-induced ischemic stroke.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of Tribulus Terrestris (TT) extract, both separately and in combination with Anacyclus Pyrethrum (AP), on male fertility parameters in Wistar rats.
results_summary: TT increased sperm count, testosterone, and LH levels, and improved Leydig, spermatogonia, and spermatid cell numbers. Combined administration with AP showed even greater improvements in sperm viability, motility, and histological parameters.
population_specificity: Male Wistar rats

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the potential of Tribulus Terrestris methanol extract for anti-Alzheimer activity and evaluate its safety.
results_summary: The study found that Tribulus Terrestris methanol extract significantly improved behavioral parameters, antioxidant enzymes, acetylcholinesterase levels, and reduced neurofibrillary tangles in an Alzheimer's disease rat model. No mortality was observed in acute toxicity testing, indicating safety at tested doses.
population_specificity: AlCl3-induced Alzheimer's disease rat model

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the anti-inflammatory and anti-fibrotic effects of Terrestrosin D (TED) from Tribulus terrestris against bleomycin-induced pulmonary inflammation and fibrosis in mice.
results_summary: TED reduced inflammatory cell infiltration, lowered levels of inflammatory and fibrotic markers (TNF-α, IL-6, IL-8, TGF-β1, PDGF-AB), decreased hydroxyproline content, and attenuated lung tissue damage in bleomycin-treated mice.
population_specificity: Male SPF mice

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the protective effects of Tribulus terrestris (TT) against mercuric chloride-induced nephrotoxicity in rats, focusing on its antioxidant and anti-inflammatory properties.
results_summary: TT at doses of 200 and 300 mg/kg significantly prevented renal injury and reduced mercury accumulation in kidney tissues, likely due to its antioxidant and anti-inflammatory effects. The higher dose (300 mg/kg) was particularly effective in decreasing renal mercury levels and mitigating oxidative stress markers.
population_specificity: Rats (n = 6 per group)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate whether gross saponins of Tribulus terrestris (GSTT) could improve erectile function in rats with type 2 diabetes mellitus-induced erectile dysfunction (T2DMED).
results_summary: GSTT significantly improved erectile function by enhancing nitric oxide levels, reducing oxidative stress, inhibiting apoptosis, and decreasing fibrosis in cavernous tissue. It showed comparable efficacy to sildenafil in increasing cGMP levels and demonstrated synergistic effects when combined with sildenafil.
population_specificity: Male rats with type 2 diabetes mellitus-induced erectile dysfunction.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Tribulus terrestris standardized extract (TTE) could improve motor dysfunction and reduce oxidative DNA damage and neurotoxicity in a rotenone-induced Parkinson's disease mouse model.
results_summary: TTE improved motor dysfunction, reduced markers of inflammation and DNA damage (8-OHdG and MTH1 expression), and suppressed oxidative stress and microglia activation (CD11b). The higher dose (10 mg/kg) also improved neuronal integrity in the substantia nigra.
population_specificity: Male Swiss albino mice with rotenone-induced Parkinson's-like symptoms.
effective_dosage: 5 mg/kg and 10 mg/kg, administered by oral gavage.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the therapeutic effects and mechanisms of GSTTF on ischemic stroke using a metabolomics approach in a rat model.
results_summary: GSTTF significantly reduced the infarct area in MCAO rats and reversed metabolic deviations by regulating fatty acids, amino acids, and carbohydrates metabolism. The study suggests GSTTF has neuroprotective effects in ischemic stroke.
population_specificity: Middle cerebral artery occlusion (MCAO) rat model

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the neuroprotective mechanisms of aqueous extract of Tribulus terrestris (AQTT) by examining its effects on inflammatory, apoptotic, and neuronal survival pathways.
results_summary: AQTT demonstrated anti-inflammatory and anti-apoptotic effects, downregulated key inflammatory and apoptotic markers, and promoted neuronal survival by modulating GSK3β/β-catenin pathways. Pretreatment with AQTT showed better efficacy than post-treatment, suggesting potential prophylactic benefits.
population_specificity: Primary cortical neurons (in vitro) and animal models (in vivo).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to systematically review clinical trials and quasi-experimental studies on the effects of Tribulus terrestris on sperm parameters in idiopathic male infertility.
results_summary: Six out of seven studies reported that Tribulus terrestris improved some or all sperm parameters (number, motility, morphology), while one quasi-experimental study without a control arm found it ineffective.
population_specificity: Men with idiopathic male infertility.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the genotoxic effects of aqueous extracts of Tribulus terrestris fruits on human peripheral blood lymphocytes.
results_summary: The study found that high concentrations (40-80 mg/L) of T. terrestris extract caused DNA damage, including micronuclei, chromosomal aberrations, and necrotic cells, while low concentrations (10-20 mg/L) showed no significant difference compared to controls.
population_specificity: Cultured human peripheral blood lymphocytes.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to elucidate the anticancer mechanism of Tribulus terrestris (TT) on MCF-7 breast cancer cells, focusing on its cytotoxic and apoptotic effects.
results_summary: TT extracts (methanolic and saponin from leaves and seeds) demonstrated cytotoxicity to MCF-7 cells while being non-toxic to non-malignant cells. The extracts induced apoptosis via both intrinsic (upregulation of Bax and p53, downregulation of Bcl-2) and extrinsic (upregulation of FADD, AIF, and caspase 8) pathways.
population_specificity: Human breast cancer MCF-7 cells and peripheral blood mononuclear cells (PBMCs).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effect of Tribulus terrestris on sexual satisfaction in postmenopausal women.
results_summary: The study found that taking T. terrestris syrup significantly increased sexual satisfaction in postmenopausal women compared to the placebo group, with statistical significance (P < 0.005).
population_specificity: Postmenopausal women referred to a health center in eastern Ahvaz.
effective_dosage: 0.9 mg of T. terrestris extract in syrup form.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the therapeutic effect of a standardized Tribulus terrestris extract on bone loss in ovariectomized rats.
results_summary: Tribulus terrestris increased bone mass to levels similar to sham-operated rats, raised DHEA levels, reduced calcium excretion, and maintained bone turnover. The extract showed a bone-protective effect, likely due to increased DHEA and calcium retention.
population_specificity: Female ovariectomized rats.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the protective effects of Tribulus terrestris saponins (TTS) on the proliferation of adipose-derived mesenchymal stem cells (ASCs) under oxidative stress induced by hydrogen peroxide (H2O2).
results_summary: The study found that TTS significantly prevented premature apoptosis in ASCs when administered both before and after exposure to oxidative stress, suggesting its potential as a protective agent against oxidative stress-induced cell damage.
population_specificity: Adipose-derived mesenchymal stem cells (ASCs) in vitro.
study_duration: Pretreatment for 2 hours or post-treatment for 24 hours.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy and safety of Tribulus terrestris in aging males with partial androgen deficiency suffering from erectile dysfunction and lower urinary tract symptoms.
results_summary: Tribulus terrestris significantly elevated total testosterone levels and improved erectile function scores, with no worsening of lower urinary tract symptoms. However, it also caused slight elevations in aspartate transaminase and prostate-specific antigen levels.
population_specificity: Aging males with partial androgen deficiency, erectile dysfunction, and lower urinary tract symptoms (n=70).
effective_dosage: Three times daily for 3 months (specific dosage not provided).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Tribulus Terrestris dry extract could protect the male reproductive system against cyclophosphamide-induced toxicity in mice.
results_summary: The study found that Tribulus Terrestris dry extract ameliorated cyclophosphamide-induced oxidative stress, histopathological damage, and reduced testosterone levels, likely due to the presence of protodioscin.
population_specificity: Male mice exposed to cyclophosphamide.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the anti-coccidial effects of Tribulus terrestris ethanol extract (TTE) against Eimeria tenella in chicks.
results_summary: TTE significantly reduced oocyst shedding in stools and increased body weight gains compared to untreated infected animals, demonstrating anti-coccidial activity.
population_specificity: 3-day-old chicks (n=30)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Tribulus terrestris fruit extract could improve symptoms of oxazolone-induced atopic dermatitis in mice and explore its mechanism of action.
results_summary: The study found that 1% TF extract combined with 0.1% HC improved atopic dermatitis symptoms, reduced skin inflammation, and modulated calcium channels and mast cell activation. TF extract also inhibited Orai-1 activity and increased TRPV3 activity in cell models.
population_specificity: Mice with oxazolone-induced atopic dermatitis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the apoptosis-inducing potential and mechanism of action of Tribulus Terrestris alkaloid extract in Jurkat E6-1 cancer cells.
results_summary: The study identified four N-feruloyltyramine derivatives in the alkaloid extract, two of which were newly reported. The extract induced dose-dependent cytotoxicity, DNA fragmentation, increased caspase-3 activity, and altered expression of critical apoptosis-related genes, suggesting anti-leukemic potential.
population_specificity: Jurkat E6-1 cancer cell line (in vitro study).
effective_dosage: LC50 140.4 μg mL-1 (sub-lethal concentration used for apoptosis assays).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether saponins from Tribulus terrestris could attenuate neuropathic pain and inflammation caused by vincristine, both peripherally and centrally.
results_summary: TT saponins effectively reduced mechanical hyperalgesia, allodynia, and inflammatory mediators (TNF-α, IL-1β, IL-6) in sciatic nerve and brain, while also restoring excitatory neurotransmitter levels (glutamate, aspartate) and improving nociceptive thresholds.
population_specificity: Animal model (neuropathic pain induced by vincristine)
study_duration: 10 days (in two 5-day cycles with a 2-day pause)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of Tribulus terrestris in treating hypoactive sexual desire disorder (HSDD) in premenopausal women and its effect on serum testosterone levels.
results_summary: Tribulus terrestris significantly improved sexual function scores (FSFI and QS-F) across multiple domains and increased free and bioavailable testosterone levels, while placebo showed no significant improvements.
population_specificity: Premenopausal women with HSDD (n=40).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the anti-inflammatory effects of tribulusamide D, a compound isolated from Tribulus Terrestris, on LPS-stimulated RAW 264.7 macrophages.
results_summary: Tribulusamide D inhibited LPS-induced production of nitric oxide and prostaglandin E2, reduced expression of inflammatory cytokines (IL-6, IL-10, TNF-α), and mediated its effects through inactivation of p38 MAPK and inhibition of NF-κB nuclear localization. The study suggests tribulusamide D has potential as a therapeutic agent for inflammatory disorders.
population_specificity: RAW 264.7 macrophages (in vitro study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects and mechanism of action of Tribulus Terrestris ethanolic extract (ETT) on osteoarthritis (OA) in an animal model.
results_summary: ETT attenuated OA symptoms by downregulating inflammatory markers (NO synthase 2, COX-2, TNF-α, IL-6) and modulating matrix metalloproteinases (MMP-2, MMP-9). The results suggest potential therapeutic benefits for inflammatory diseases like OA.
population_specificity: LEW/SSNHSD rats with MIA-induced osteoarthritis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the mechanisms by which Tribulus Terrestris (TT) extracts enhance muscle weight and performance in rats undergoing high-intensity exercise, focusing on androgens, IGF-1, and their receptors.
results_summary: TT extracts increased testosterone and IGF-1 plasma levels, upregulated AR and IGF-1R protein expression, and enhanced muscle weight and myosin heavy chain (MHC) levels in rats performing high-intensity exercise. The study suggests TT may promote skeletal muscle mass and athletic performance.
population_specificity: Sprague-Dawley rats undergoing high-intensity exercise.
effective_dosage: 120 mg/kg, administered intragastrically 30 minutes prior to training.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of Tribulus terrestris hydro-alcoholic extract on cerulein-induced acute pancreatitis in mice, focusing on its antioxidant, anti-inflammatory, analgesic, and antimicrobial properties.
results_summary: T. terrestris extract at doses of 200 and 400 mg/kg (oral) and 400 mg/kg (intraperitoneal) reduced pancreatic tissue myeloperoxidase activity, serum amylase and lipase levels, and improved histological parameters in mice with induced acute pancreatitis.
population_specificity: Mice (n=6 per group) with cerulein-induced acute pancreatitis.
study_duration: Single administration before pancreatitis induction, with euthanasia 5 hours after the last cerulein injection.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effectiveness of a hydroalcoholic extract combination of Withania somnifera and Tribulus terrestris in treating letrozole-induced polycystic ovarian syndrome (PCOS) in rats.
results_summary: The combination of WS and TT normalized the estrus cycle, reversed hormonal imbalances, reduced serum cholesterol, and restored ovarian and uterine weights to normal levels. Histopathological analysis showed nearly normal ovarian tissue.
population_specificity: Female Wistar rats with letrozole-induced PCOS.
effective_dosage: 198 mg/kg of the combined hydroalcoholic extract (WS and TT).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of Tribulus terrestris, combined with other herbs, on reducing menopausal symptoms in postmenopausal women.
results_summary: The study found that the Aphrodit capsule (containing Tribulus terrestris and other herbs) significantly reduced menopausal symptoms compared to the placebo group, demonstrating its efficacy.
population_specificity: 80 postmenopausal women aged 50-60 years.
effective_dosage: 40 mg of Tribulus terrestris per capsule, taken twice daily.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of Tribulus terrestris for treating hypoactive sexual desire disorder in postmenopausal women and its effect on serum testosterone levels.
results_summary: Tribulus terrestris significantly improved sexual function domains (desire, arousal/lubrication, pain, anorgasmia) and increased free and bioavailable testosterone levels compared to placebo. Few side effects were reported, and the supplement was deemed safe.
population_specificity: Postmenopausal women with diminished libido.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the efficacy and safety of Tribulus Terrestris (Tribestan) versus placebo for treating erectile dysfunction (ED) and hypoactive sexual desire disorder (HSDD) in men, while also evaluating its impact on blood lipid levels.
results_summary: Tribulus Terrestris significantly improved IIEF scores and other sexual function measures compared to placebo, with no significant difference in adverse events between groups. The therapy was well-tolerated, with no serious drug-related adverse events reported.
population_specificity: 180 males aged 18-65 with mild to moderate ED, with or without HSDD, including those with hypertension, diabetes mellitus, and metabolic syndrome.
effective_dosage: 3×2 film-coated tablets daily (each containing 250mg Tribulus Terrestris extract, standardized to ≥112.5mg furostanol saponins).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the tolerability and efficacy of a combination supplement containing Tribulus Terrestris for improving sexual quality of life in patients with premature ejaculation.
results_summary: The study found significant improvements in intravaginal ejaculatory latency time (IELT) and Premature Ejaculation Diagnostic Tool (PEDT) scores in patients taking the supplement compared to controls. Significant differences were also observed in IIEF-5 and FSH scores.
population_specificity: Patients with premature ejaculation attending urological centers.
effective_dosage: One tablet per day (exact dosage of Tribulus Terrestris not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of direct addition of Tribulus terrestris extract on human sperm parameters, including motility, viability, and DNA fragmentation.
results_summary: The study found that incubating human semen with 40 and 50 µg/mL of Tribulus terrestris extract significantly improved sperm motility, progressive motility, curvilinear velocity, and viability over 60 to 120 minutes.
population_specificity: 40 healthy male volunteers

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of Tribulus terrestris saponins on exercise performance and the underlying mechanisms in an overtraining rat model.
results_summary: TT saponins improved exercise performance, increased body and gastrocnemius mass, elevated serum testosterone levels, and modulated androgen-AR axis and IGF-1R signaling in overtraining rats.
population_specificity: Rats subjected to an overtraining model
effective_dosage: 120 mg/kg body mass, administered 30 minutes before each training session
study_duration: Duration not specified in the abstract

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compile a database for further investigation of the phytopharmacological properties of Tribulus Terrestris to validate its traditional uses and explore potential applications.
results_summary: The study highlighted Tribulus Terrestris's diverse pharmacological activities, including aphrodisiac, anti-inflammatory, antimicrobial, and antioxidant effects, as well as potential immunomodulatory, hepatoprotective, hypolipidemic, anthelmintic, and anticarcinogenic applications. It emphasized its traditional use for infertility and libido enhancement.
population_specificity: Not specified (general traditional use and pharmacological potential discussed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Tribulus terrestris improves serum testosterone, luteinizing hormone levels, and semen parameters in males with unexplained infertility.
results_summary: The study found no statistically significant differences in testosterone (total and free), LH levels, or semen parameters (sperm concentration, motility, abnormal forms) before and after treatment. Tribulus terrestris was ineffective in treating idiopathic infertility.
population_specificity: Thirty male patients with idiopathic infertility.
effective_dosage: 750 mg daily in three divided doses.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of Tribulus terrestris on semen quality and physiological parameters in men with abnormal semen evaluation.
results_summary: The study found significant improvements in body fat percentage, lean muscle mass, dihydrotestosterone levels, and semen parameters (sperm concentration, motility, and liquefaction time). Protodioscin, the main phytochemical in Tribulus, was noted to enhance germ cell proliferation and seminiferous tubule growth.
population_specificity: 65 men with abnormal semen evaluation.
effective_dosage: 250 mg of Tribulus terrestris dried extract per capsule (Androsten®).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of Tribulus terrestris on sexual function in menopausal women with sexual dysfunction.
results_summary: Tribulus terrestris significantly improved sexual function in menopausal women, particularly in desire, foreplay, arousal, and comfort during intercourse, but not in orgasm or sexual satisfaction. No significant adverse effects were reported.
population_specificity: 60 postmenopausal women with sexual dysfunction.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the genetic diversity and structure of different populations of Tribulus terrestris from north India using newly developed SSR markers.
results_summary: The study identified high genetic diversity among T. terrestris populations, with 76% of genetic variance within populations and 24% among populations. The newly developed SSR markers revealed three distinct genetic groups, primarily corresponding to Rajasthan, Punjab, and Haryana regions, with some intermixing.
population_specificity: T. terrestris plant populations from north India (Rajasthan, Punjab, Haryana).
study_duration: Not applicable (genetic study, no intervention duration).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of Tribulus terrestris (TT) on oxidized LDL-induced endothelial dysfunction in human umbilical vein endothelial cells (HUVECs).
results_summary: TT suppressed ox-LDL-induced HUVEC proliferation and apoptosis, improved cytoskeletal integrity and cell migration, regulated eNOS synthesis and ROS generation, and modulated key genes in the JAK2/STAT3 and PI3K/AKT pathways, showing efficacy comparable to valsartan.
population_specificity: Human umbilical vein endothelial cells (HUVECs) in vitro.
study_duration: Pre-incubation for 60 minutes followed by 24-hour ox-LDL exposure.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the protective effects of Tribulus Terrestris fruit extract on metronidazole-induced testicular and sperm-related alterations in mice.
results_summary: Tribulus Terrestris partially restored testicular weight, spermatogenesis, antioxidant enzyme activity, and sperm count at 100 mg/kg/day and fully restored these parameters at 200 mg/kg/day when co-administered with metronidazole.
population_specificity: Adult Swiss strain mice

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the antiandrogenic properties of Tribulus Terrestris and its efficacy in managing PCOS symptoms in rat models.
results_summary: Tribulus Terrestris demonstrated antiandrogenic activity in vitro and normalized estrous cyclicity, steroidal hormonal levels, and ovarian follicular growth in PCOS-induced rats.
population_specificity: Female rat models with PCOS induced by estradiol valerate.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of N-trans-ρ-caffeoyl tyramine (CT) from Tribulus terrestris on inflammatory responses, specifically NO production, pro-inflammatory cytokines, and COX-2 expression in LPS-stimulated RAW 264.7 cells.
results_summary: The study found that both the ethanolic extract of T. terrestris (EETT) and CT inhibited NO, TNF-α, IL-6, and IL-10 production in a dose-dependent manner. CT also suppressed COX-2 expression, PGE2 production, and p-JNK protein expression, indicating potent anti-inflammatory effects.
population_specificity: LPS-stimulated RAW 264.7 cells (murine macrophage cell line).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the antimicrobial activity of Tribulus terrestris extract alone and in combination with Capsella bursa-pastoris and Glycyrrhiza glabra against six bacterial pathogens.
results_summary: Tribulus terrestris extract showed good antibacterial activity against all tested bacteria, with a synergistic effect observed when combined with the other two extracts, resulting in lower MIC values. The mixed extract was more effective than any single extract alone.
population_specificity: In vitro study (bacterial pathogens: Streptococcus mutans, Streptococcus sanguis, Actinomyces viscosus, Enterococcus faecalis, Staphylococcus aureus, and Escherichia coli).
effective_dosage: MIC values for Tribulus terrestris ranged from 35.0 to 20.0 mg/ml; mixed extract ranged from 12.5 to 5.0 mg/ml.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the safety and efficacy of Tribulus terrestris extract in treating female sexual dysfunction.
results_summary: The study found statistically significant improvements in Female Sexual Function Index (FSFI) scores and DHEA levels, though serum and free testosterone levels decreased. Most adverse events were gastrointestinal-related, with no significant changes in physical examinations post-treatment.
population_specificity: Female patients of reproductive age presenting with sexual dysfunction.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of Tribulus terrestris on testosterone levels (total and free) and erectile function in aging males with partial androgen deficiency.
results_summary: Tribulus terrestris significantly increased testosterone levels (total and free) and improved erectile function (measured by IIEF-5), but did not significantly affect luteinizing hormone (LH) levels. There was a significant correlation between testosterone levels and erectile function improvement.
population_specificity: 30 male patients with partial androgen deficiency in aging males (PADAM).
effective_dosage: 750 mg/day in 3 divided doses (250 mg each).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to analyze the impact of saponin extract from Tribulus terrestris on cell processes, particularly apoptosis and metastasizing, in breast carcinoma cell lines.
results_summary: The study found that TT saponin extract reduced CXCR4 expression in both MCF7 and MCF10A cell lines, while CCR7 and BCL2 levels decreased only in tumorigenic MCF7 cells, suggesting cell-specific effects on apoptosis and metastasis.
population_specificity: Breast carcinoma cell lines (MCF7 and MCF10A).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of Libicare®, a supplement containing Tribulus Terrestris, in improving sexual function and hormone levels in postmenopausal women with sexual dysfunction.
results_summary: The study found significant improvements in sexual function (FSFI score) and testosterone levels, along with a decrease in SHBG levels, suggesting Libicare® may enhance sexual health in postmenopausal women.
population_specificity: Postmenopausal women aged 45-65 with a risk of sexual dysfunction (FSFI < 25.83).
effective_dosage: 2 tablets of Libicare® daily (specific Tribulus Terrestris dosage not detailed).

study_goal: To critically analyze the evidence supporting Tribulus Terrestris as an aphrodisiac and reassess its purported androgen-enhancing properties.
results_summary: The study found that Tribulus Terrestris may help treat erectile dysfunction and sexual desire issues, but evidence for its androgen-enhancing effects is inconclusive. Emerging evidence suggests its aphrodisiac effects may involve endothelium and nitric oxide-dependent mechanisms.
population_specificity: Humans and animals (not further specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effect of Tribulus Terrestris on testosterone levels in humans and animals by reviewing existing literature.
results_summary: The study found limited evidence supporting Tribulus Terrestris's effectiveness in increasing testosterone levels in humans, with only animal studies showing significant increases. Marketing claims were deemed unsubstantiated, and nitric oxide release was suggested as an alternative mechanism for observed effects.
population_specificity: Healthy human subjects and various animal species.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the protective effects of aqueous leaves' extract of Trichopus zeylanicus (ALETZ) against ibuprofen-induced liver and intestinal toxicity in rats.
results_summary: Pre-treatment with ALETZ normalized adverse effects caused by ibuprofen, modulating oxidative stress, inflammation, and apoptosis markers, indicating its protective mechanism.
population_specificity: Male albino rats (30 total, divided into five groups).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the anti-fatigue effects of Trichopus zeylanicus whole plant powder in young Sprague-Dawley rats and aged normal and mutant Ames dwarf mice.
results_summary: Trichopus zeylanicus significantly improved fatigue resistance in young rats and increased mobility and swim time in aged mice, with effects observed at doses of 250 and 500 mg/kg. Amphetamine-mimetic activity was excluded, supporting its potential as a non-stimulant anti-fatigue agent.
population_specificity: Young Sprague-Dawley rats and aged normal and mutant Ames dwarf mice.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the antioxidant properties of Trichopus zeylanicus and its potential mechanisms for combating fatigue.
results_summary: Trichopus zeylanicus demonstrated significant free radical scavenging, reduced lipid peroxidation, inhibited lipoxygenase activity, exhibited iron-chelating properties, and protected against reactive oxygen species-induced DNA damage. Its antioxidant activity was attributed to NADH, polyphenols, and sulfhydryl compounds.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro study, no human participants mentioned).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the mast cell-stabilizing effects of Trichopus zeylanicus leaf and its potential to protect against E. coli-induced abdominal sepsis.
results_summary: Trichopus zeylanicus leaf inhibited antigen-induced degranulation of sensitized peritoneal mast cells in mice and reduced mast cell ratios in peritoneal exudate cells. However, it did not protect against E. coli-induced sepsis, and the butanol fraction of its methanol extract showed mast cell-stabilizing effects in rats but not in vitro.
population_specificity: Mice and rats

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the immunomodulatory and anti-tumor effects of Trichopus zeylanicus in mice, as well as its impact on gastrointestinal function.
results_summary: Trichopus zeylanicus administration increased thymocytes, splenic lymphocytes, total blood leucocytes, and peritoneal macrophages without affecting hemoglobin or body weight. It also protected mice from tumor growth when challenged with EAC ascitic tumor cells and slightly reduced intestinal motility.
population_specificity: Mice
effective_dosage: 0.5 ml of 2% water suspension per mouse daily

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Trichopus zeylanicus leaf extract has aphrodisiac effects in male mice and assess its safety and efficacy.
results_summary: The ethanol extract of Trichopus zeylanicus increased sexual behavior in male mice, with effects being concentration-dependent and heat-sensitive. Daily administration for 6 days was more effective than a single dose, and offspring were normal in growth, litter size, and sex ratio. Water and n-hexane extracts showed no activity.
population_specificity: Male mice
effective_dosage: Single dose (200 mg/kg) or daily administration for 6 days

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify tryptophan metabolites as potential diagnostic biomarkers for differentiated thyroid cancer (DTC).
results_summary: The study found significant differences in 11 tryptophan metabolites between DTC patients and healthy controls, with five metabolites (nicotinamide, 3-hydroxyanthranilic acid, 5-hydroxytryptophan, melatonin, and indole-3-propionic acid) identified as independent predictors. The diagnostic model based on these metabolites showed high sensitivity (84.8%), specificity (90.0%), and an AUC of 0.932.
population_specificity: 105 DTC patients and 50 healthy controls.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether modulating endogenous tryptophan metabolism via a programmable probiotic (NE-EcN-pA) could alleviate intestinal inflammation and restore gut health in inflammatory bowel disease (IBD).
results_summary: NE-EcN-pA improved kynurenic acid and xanthurenic acid levels, alleviated intestinal inflammation, restored the epithelial barrier, enhanced gut microbiota diversity, and increased short-chain fatty acid content in the colon of UC mice.
population_specificity: UC (ulcerative colitis) mice

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the roles of Tryptophan metabolism pathways (Kynurenine and Indole) in disease progression, tumor immunity, and therapeutic efficacy.
results_summary: The study found that Tryptophan metabolites influence tumor growth, immune resistance, and treatment effectiveness through multiple mechanisms, including NAD+ regulation, angiogenesis, and gut microbiota interactions. Conflicting effects were noted between the Kynurenine and Indole pathways on tumor phenotypes.
population_specificity: Not specified (general focus on disease mechanisms in digestive, nervous, and urinary systems).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the role of the tryptophan pathway and IDO1/IDO2 upregulation in cetuximab-resistant colorectal cancer (CRC) and assess the therapeutic potential of combining cetuximab with the IDO inhibitor epacadostat.
results_summary: The study found that cetuximab-resistant CRC patients exhibited activation of the tryptophan pathway and elevated IDO1/IDO2 levels. Combining cetuximab with epacadostat effectively inhibited tumor growth, reduced kynurenine levels, and enhanced anti-tumor immune responses by promoting CD8+ T lymphocyte infiltration and M1 macrophage polarization.
population_specificity: Cetuximab-resistant colorectal cancer (CRC) patients and corresponding in vitro and in vivo models.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether tryptophan (Trp) levels and indoleamine 2,3-dioxygenase (IDO) activity were associated with mortality in patients with coronary artery disease (CAD).
results_summary: Higher tryptophan levels were negatively associated with death (HR = 0.558), indicating better survival, while higher IDO activity predicted worse survival (HR = 2.925). Patients with Trp concentrations below the median had worse survival than those with higher levels.
population_specificity: 170 participants with CAD, median age 62 years, 68.8% male, hospitalized for acute coronary syndrome or elective percutaneous coronary intervention.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if a supplement containing tryptophan, combined with other ingredients, could improve sleep initiation, quality, and post-wake mood in adults with self-reported sleep difficulties.
results_summary: The treatment significantly reduced sleep onset latency, improved sleep quality, and lowered postprandial glucose response. Participants also reported feeling more relaxed and improved vigor the next morning, though no cognitive effects were observed.
population_specificity: Adults aged 25-50 with self-reported difficulties in sleep initiation.
effective_dosage: 120 mg tryptophan (as part of a whey protein blend), administered with other ingredients.
study_duration: 14 days per intervention phase, with a 28-day washout period.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize current knowledge on the influence of tryptophan and its metabolite serotonin on metabolic and behavioral regulation, focusing on sex differences and the brain-gut-microbiome axis.
results_summary: The study found that tryptophan and serotonin play essential roles in metabolic and behavioral regulation via the brain-gut-microbiome axis, with sex differences influencing feeding and affective behaviors. It proposed the gut microbiome as a therapeutic target for serotonin-related disorders, highlighting potential differences in treatment efficacy between men and women.
population_specificity: Human and animal studies (not specified further).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the role of tryptophan catabolism, mediated by IL4I1, in glioblastoma multiforme (GBM) progression and its potential as a therapeutic target.
results_summary: The study found that IL4I1, a tryptophan metabolic enzyme, was upregulated in GBM and promoted tumor progression by inhibiting ferroptosis through the Nrf2 signaling pathway. Indole-3-pyruvic acid (I3P), derived from tryptophan, was shown to scavenge free radicals and attenuate Nrf2 ubiquitination, thereby enhancing anti-ferroptotic effects.
population_specificity: Glioblastoma multiforme (GBM) patients and GBM xenografts.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the therapeutic effects of Shenqi granules (SQF) on cerebral ischemia-reperfusion injury (CIRI) and its regulatory effects on gut microbiota, particularly focusing on tryptophan metabolism.
results_summary: SQF improved cognitive functions and reduced cerebral infarct volume in rats with CIRI, with its protective effects linked to modulation of tryptophan metabolism and gut microbiota. Key metabolites like kynurenic acid and dopamine interacted with NFE2L2/NRF2, suggesting a mechanism for SQF's efficacy.
population_specificity: Rats with cerebral ischemia-reperfusion injury (CIRI).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to report a case of priapism linked to Tribulus terrestris consumption and highlight potential serious side effects of non-FDA-approved herbal supplements.
results_summary: The study found that Tribulus terrestris consumption led to a 72-hour priapism in a patient, requiring surgical intervention (Ebbehoj shunt) and resulting in negative post-episode sexual function outcomes. The abstract warns about serious side effects of such supplements.
population_specificity: 36-year-old Caucasian male

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Fe3O4 nanoparticles functionalized with chitosan (Fe3O4@CS) could mimic tryptophan hydroxylase activity to restore serotonin synthesis and treat depression.
results_summary: Fe3O4@CS nanoparticles successfully catalyzed the conversion of tryptophan to 5-hydroxytryptophan, restoring serotonin levels and improving depressive-like behaviors in a mouse model. The treatment enhanced neuronal signal transduction and compensated for deactivated tryptophan hydroxylase in stressed neurons.
population_specificity: Depression mouse model

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether baseline fecal tryptophan-metabolites could predict dietary therapy outcomes in pediatric Crohn's disease.
results_summary: Baseline fecal kynurenine levels were significantly higher in non-remission patients, and specific tryptophan metabolite ratios (e.g., serotonin/kynurenine) showed strong predictive power for dietary therapy-induced remission.
population_specificity: Pediatric patients with mild-to-moderate Crohn's disease.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how Wuji Wan (WJW) modulates tryptophan metabolism via the gut microbiota to improve intestinal barrier function and reduce inflammation in a murine colitis model.
results_summary: WJW increased Lactobacillus abundance, facilitating tryptophan conversion into indole derivatives (IAA and IA), which activated the AhR pathway, reduced inflammation, and restored intestinal barrier proteins. These effects were gut microbiota-dependent and confirmed by AhR antagonist pre-treatment.
population_specificity: Murine (mouse) colitis model.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the role of CB2R in NAFLD and its underlying mechanism related to microbial community and tryptophan metabolism.
results_summary: The study found that disordered tryptophan metabolites, such as indolelactic acid (ILA) and xanthurenic acid, mediated by gut dysbiosis, were linked to NAFLD severity. Enriched tryptophan metabolites like ILA aggravated NAFLD phenotypes in both in vitro and in vivo experiments.
population_specificity: High-fat diet-induced NAFLD model in mice and NAFLD patients.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of rumen-protected L-tryptophan (RPL-T) supplementation on starch digestion, melatonin secretion, and gastrointestinal hormone levels in Holstein steers.
results_summary: RPL-T supplementation significantly reduced D-glucose content, increased serum cholecystokinin (CCK) and melatonin levels, and lowered starch disappearance rates in the GI tract compared to the control, with no significant differences between RPL-T dosage groups. Digestion was improved in all treatment groups.
population_specificity: Holstein steers (201 ± 24 kg)
effective_dosage: 19.1 mg/kg BW, 95.6 mg/kg BW, and 191.1 mg/kg BW

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how host-derived miR-205-5p and tryptophan metabolites (indole-3-acetamide, indole-3-acetic acid, and indole-3-carboxaldehyde) from Lactobacillus reuteri alleviate constipation in mice treated with electroacupuncture.
results_summary: The study found that tryptophan metabolites from Lactobacillus reuteri alleviated loperamide-induced constipation in mice, suggesting a role in enhancing intestinal motility through microbiome modulation.
population_specificity: Loperamide-induced constipated mice treated with electroacupuncture.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether kynurenine (KYN), a tryptophan derivative, affects progesterone biosynthesis in luteinized porcine granulosa luteal (pGL) cells.
results_summary: KYN disrupted progesterone biosynthesis by decreasing the expression of STAR and HSD3B in pGL cells, along with downregulating transcription factors GATA4, GATA6, and CEBPB through AHR activation. The findings suggest a novel inhibitory link between KYN and progesterone production.
population_specificity: In vitro luteinized porcine granulosa luteal (pGL) cells.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the excited-state kinetics of tryptophan and NADH to understand metabolic changes associated with liver cirrhosis and hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC).
